Parametric Production Planning
items.abstract: <jats:p> This paper proposes a heuristic approach to the determination of work force and production levels. The existence of two feed-back rules (one for work force and one for production) is postulated. The universe of possible parameters is searched to find the set of parameters that provides the lowest cost or highest profit for a particular firm. Each set of parameters is evaluated by comparing the costs or profits resulting from the application of rules bearing these parameter values to a likely sequence of sales forecasts and actual sales. Decision rules formed in this way give cost and profit results nearly equal to those resulting from the application of the optimal techniques to purely mathematical problems. In more complex and more realistic situations, the results obtained by Parametric Production Planning may be superior to those achieved by a linear programming approach or a linear decision rule. </jats:p>

title: Systems Approach to Reservoir Engineering: Optimum Development Planning
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Reservoir development is a problem which does not appear to have attracted much attention in the literature. This problem arises whenever the future planning for a newly discovered or partially developed reservoir is under review and the following question is posed: "What drilling and/or production policy should be adopted to maximize the return from a given operation in the presence of practical constraints?"</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>This question is difficult because of the many factors involved – some of which are not known with any degree of certainty. At the present time, it is not possible to provide a completely satisfactory answer; but some of the salient points may be studied and considerable insight concerning the nature of the problem may be gained. In this paper, the problem is approached via systems theory; i.e., the reservoir is considered to be a dynamic system the behaviour of which is reflected in the pressure- production history. This concept leads to a simple model in terms of which development is considered as a control problem.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>This unconventional approach is shown to be consistent with some current reservoir engineering practices, but it has distinct advantages over them because it is possible to specify economic criteria as part of the formulation and, hence, to consider the question of optimal policy. On this basis, reservoir development is the counterpart of the optimal control problem with which so much of the modern systems theory is concerned.</jats:p>
                  <jats:p>The separate phases of a systems study – systems identification and specification of control policies – are discussed in the context of reservoir development.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>

National Aerospace Planning
container-title: The Journal of the Royal Aeronautical Society
items.abstract:
<jats:p>Summary:—There is no doubt of the need for strong central planning of aeronautical research and development as advocated by the Post-Plowden Working Party of the Royal Aeronautical Society (pp. 391-392 June 1967 “Journal“).</jats:p><jats:p>But there are many other problems in the efficient use of aerospace resources which are equally in need of attention by the Society. Among the most important are:
<jats:list list-type="number"><jats:list-item><jats:p>The complementary role of improved industrial and project management.</jats:p></jats:list-item><jats:list-item><jats:p>The need to deal separately with the distinct problems of Defence, Civil Aviation and Space—in particular the improvement of Defence procurement methods.</jats:p></jats:list-item><jats:list-item><jats:p>The need to discover the correct commercial and engineering bases (as distinct from political bases) for European collaboration.</jats:p></jats:list-item><jats:list-item><jats:p>The need to complement the work of a strong planning organisation by providing facilities for high-level and informed technical debate, wherever possible in public.</jats:p></jats:list-item></jats:list></jats:p>

title: Planning Tomorrow Today through Successive Focusing
items.abstract: <jats:p> Techniques for product planning are legion; but an integrated method, embracing an infinite variety of situations, has yet to be devised. </jats:p><jats:p> The author of this article attempts this by introducing the concept of the dynamic product area, which does more than answer the traditional question: “What business are we in?” </jats:p>

title: Ideology and Politics in Economic Planning: The Problem of Indian Agricultural Development Strategy
items.abstract: <jats:p>For the first time since independence, economic planners in India are experiencing a serious crisis of confidence. Although there has always been some debate on alternative policies and programs, the central assumptions of development planning have remained unchallenged since the 1930's. Now, in contrast, the very core of economic development strategy has become the target of open and bitter criticism. The final draft of the Fourth Five Year Plan has been delayed for more than a year, and the end of fundamental disagreements seems nowhere in sight.</jats:p>
